title: Drew Brees should have won the 2011 MVP over Aaron Rodgers
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)


Drew Brees 2010-11 regular season was one of the best in NFL history, but his team help him back from winning an MVP. Setting a new record for passing yards in a regular season which still stand as second all time, Brees was able to top two in MVP finalist behind Aaron Rodgers with Rodgers winning the award. This win was backed up by a 15-1 regular season record and stellar 45/6 Touchdown to Interception ratio. Rodgers also had the ball more than Brees did, since his defense had 38 takeaways comapared to the Saints 16 total takeaways.


Code
brees <- read_csv("data/Brees2011 - Sheet1.csv") %>%
mutate(Week=as.numeric(Week), Player="Drew Brees", .before=1)


New names:
Rows: 16 Columns: 12
── Column specification
──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── Delimiter: "," chr
(4): ...2, OT, Rec, Opp...5 dbl (8): Week, Tm, Opp...7, 1stD, TotYd, PassY,
RushY, TO
ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. ℹ
Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
• `` -> `...2`
• `Opp` -> `Opp...5`
• `Opp` -> `Opp...7`




Code
rodgers <- read_csv("data/Rodgers2011 - Sheet1.csv") %>%
mutate(Week=as.numeric(Week), Player="Aaron Rodgers", .before=1)


New names:
Rows: 15 Columns: 12
── Column specification
──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── Delimiter: "," chr
(3): ...2, Rec, Opp...5 dbl (8): Week, Tm, Opp...7, 1stD, TotYd, PassY, RushY,
TO lgl (1): OT
ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. ℹ
Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
• `` -> `...2`
• `Opp` -> `Opp...5`
• `Opp` -> `Opp...7`




Code
brees %>%
  bind_rows(rodgers)


New names:
New names:
• `...2` -> `...3`
• `Opp...5` -> `Opp...6`
• `Opp...7` -> `Opp...8`


# A tibble: 31 × 13
   Player  Week ...3  OT    Rec   Opp...6    Tm Opp...8 `1stD` TotYd PassY RushY
   <chr>  <dbl> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr>   <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
 1 Drew …     1 L     <NA>  0-1   Green …    34      42     27   477   396    81
 2 Drew …     2 W     <NA>  1-1   Chicag…    30      13     16   382   264   118
 3 Drew …     3 W     <NA>  2-1   Housto…    40      33     27   454   354   100
 4 Drew …     4 W     <NA>  3-1   Jackso…    23      10     30   503   326   177
 5 Drew …     5 W     <NA>  4-1   Caroli…    30      27     27   444   343   101
 6 Drew …     6 L     <NA>  4-2   Tampa …    20      26     20   453   383    70
 7 Drew …     7 W     <NA>  5-2   Indian…    62       7     36   557   321   236
 8 Drew …     8 L     <NA>  5-3   St. Lo…    21      31      8   283   227    56
 9 Drew …     9 W     <NA>  6-3   Tampa …    27      16     25   453   258   195
10 Drew …    10 W     OT    7-3   Atlant…    26      23     18   363   322    41
# … with 21 more rows, and 1 more variable: TO <dbl>


Taking a week by week look, you see that Brees really starts to separate himself near the half way point of the season passing yards wise.


Code
ggplot() +
  geom_line(data = brees, aes(x = Week, y = PassY), color = "#D3BC8D") + 
  geom_line(data = rodgers, aes(x = Week, y = PassY), color = "darkgreen") + 
  geom_text(
    aes(x=5, y=250, label="Top 10 QB Average Passing Yards"),
    color= "red"
      )+
  geom_hline(yintercept = 293.88, color="red") +
  labs(x= "Week of Season",
       y = "Passing Yards per Game", 
       title = "Aaron Rodgers won the 2011 NFL MVP over Drew Brees",
       subtitle = "Brees had more yards this year, and broke an NFL record for passing yards in a season.",
       caption = "Source: Pro Football Reference | Graphic by Eldridge Jensen") +
  theme_gray() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 17, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 11),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )





Code
ggsave("image.png")




Code
  players <- read_csv("data/breesvrodgers - Sheet1.csv")


Rows: 2 Columns: 19
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (4): Player, Tm, Pos, QBrec
dbl (15): Rk, Age, G, GS, Cmp, Att, Cmp%, Yds, TD, TD%, Int, Int%, Y/G, Rate...

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.




Code
qb <- players %>% 
  group_by(Pos, Player) %>% 
  summarise(
    TotalTDs = sum(TD),
    TotalInts = sum(Int),
  ) %>% 
  filter(Pos == "QB")


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'Pos'. You can override using the `.groups`
argument.




Code
totals <- qb %>% 
  pivot_longer(
    cols=starts_with("Total"), 
    names_to="Type", 
    values_to="Totals") 




Code
ggplot(totals, aes(x=Player, weight=Totals, fill=Type)) + 
  geom_bar() + 
  coord_flip()







Code
ggplot(totals, aes(x=reorder(Player, Totals), weight=Totals, fill=Type)) +
  geom_bar() + 
  coord_flip() +
labs(
    y = "Total TD/Ints",
    x = "Player",
    title = "Drew Brees had more Touchdowns, but also more Interceptions",
    subtitle = "Aaron Rodgers had a better TD/Int ratio.",
     caption = "Source: Pro Football Reference | Graphic by Eldridge Jensen"
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 14, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )





While Aaron Rodgers did have a better Touchdown to Interception ratio, Brees had more Touchdowns, and a higher completion percentage too.


Code
  players <- read_csv("data/passingdata2011.csv")


Rows: 20 Columns: 19
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (4): Player, Tm, Pos, QBrec
dbl (15): Rk, Age, G, GS, Cmp, Att, Cmp%, Yds, TD, TD%, Int, Int%, Y/G, Rate...

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.




Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data = players, aes(x = `Cmp%`))







Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data = players, aes(x = `Cmp%`, weight = `Cmp%`))







Code
db <- players %>% filter(Player == "Drew Brees")




Code
ar <- players %>% filter(Player == "Aaron Rodgers")




Code
ggplot() +
  geom_bar(data = players, aes(x = reorder(Player, `Cmp%`), weight = `Cmp%`), fill = "light grey")+
   geom_bar(data = db, aes(x = reorder(Player, `Cmp%`), weight = `Cmp%`), fill ="#D3BC8D") +
   geom_bar(data = ar, aes(x = reorder(Player, `Cmp%`), weight = `Cmp%`), fill ="darkgreen") +
  coord_flip()+
  theme_minimal()+
  labs(
   title = "Drew Brees led the League in Completion Percentage",
   subtitle = "Brees also led the league in passing yards per game",
   x= "Player",
   y= "Completion Percentage"
  )





Drew Brees in 2011 won the AP Offensive Player of the Year award, winning 86 percent of the votes that year. Brees statistically was the best QB statistically this year, he was number one in passing yards where Rodgers was 5th in the league this year. Brees was also number one in passing TDs where Rodgers was second. Brees also set a new NFL record with 71.4% completion percentage. Brees was on an absolute tear this year in the regular season, winning nine games in a row before they lost to the San Francisco 49ers in the Divisional round of the playoffs.

title: SportsBlog
text:
Drew Brees should have won the 2011 MVP over Aaron Rodgers







football

title: About
text: This is Eldridge Jensen’s sports blog, I am a Sophomore Sports Media Communications Major. I am a student in SPMC 350 and I am currently working on making a data set that show why Drew Brees should have won the 2011 NFL MVP over Aaron Rodgers.

title: Drew Brees vs Aaron Rodgers
text:
library(tidyverse)

Drew Brees 2010-11 regular season was one of the best in NFL history, but his team help him back from winning an MVP. Setting a new record for passing yards in a regular season which still stand as second all time, Brees was able to top two in MVP finalist behind Aaron Rodgers with Rodgers winning the award. This win was backed up by a 15-1 regular season record and stellar 45/6 Touchdown to Interception ratio. Rodgers also had the ball more than Brees did, since his defense had 38 takeaways comapared to the Saints 16 total takeaways.

mutate(Week=as.numeric(Week), Player="Drew Brees", .before=1)

While Aaron Rodgers did have a better Touchdown to Interception ratio, Brees had more Touchdowns, and a higher completion percentage too.

Brees was on an absolute tear this year in the regular season, winning nine games in a row before they lost to the San Francisco 49ers in the Divisional round of the playoffs.
